newsitem.title: SYRIA: Syria aims to export 125,000 tonnes of cotton.
newsitem.headline: Syria aims to export 125,000 tonnes of cotton.

text.p: Syria expects to export around 125,000 tonnes of ginned cotton from this year's harvest after meeting the needs of the local market, Ahmed Suhad Jubara, chief of the state-owned cotton marketing organisation (CMO), said on Monday.
He told Reuters production reached a record 725,000 tonnes this year, and that the CMO, the sole marketer of cotton in Syria, had bought 712,000 tonnes from farmers during the past seven weeks.
The rest would be bought in the next two days.
Syria produced around 650,000 tonnes of raw cotton in 1995, and average output between 1991 and 1995 was around 604,000 tonnes, Jubara said.
It had made great strides this year in boosting yields, which had reached a record 3.4 tonnes per hectare, compared with 3.1 tonnes in 1995 and only 1.6 tonnes in 1970.
This had allowed a decline in the area devoted to cotton to 216,581 hectares from 236,133 in 1970, freeing up land for other strategic products, especially wheat.
Syria's main markets for ginned cotton were Italy, France, Germany, Switzerland, Spain, Portugal, Russia, China and Poland.
Cotton was also exported to Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt, Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates.
"The success of our external marketing policy is based on our respect of contracts and accuracy in dates of delivery and keeping the high quality of our products," the GEGMC chief said.
He said Syrian cotton also attracted strong demand because it was still harvested by hand.
More than 20 percent of Syria's population was involved in the cotton industry and affiliated sectors.
Syrian industry minister Ahmed Nezamuldin told Reuters last week the government and the private sector were investing around $1.27 billion to boost the cotton industry and to build new mills.
Nezamuldin said the ministry was working to reduce the sale of ginned cotton and expand exports of spun cotton. The difference in price could be as high as $7,000 per tonne for some grades.
